Mart and a data Mart for us is just aggregated data with business rules applied so that somebody who was using

at aggregating data so we advise everybody to use aggregate queries wherever they possibly can when going

announced a feature last week in fact to provide a solution for the remaining 13%
of customers it's called concurrency scaling it's particularly for supporting this sort of
bursty usage and to increase the concurrency of the system now the way it
works is as if as queries come in and we see that there is any any amount of
queuing what we're able to do is spin up additional clusters let's just call
these additional clusters concurrent clusters so we spin up additional concurrent clusters one or more as
needed and the concurrent clusters can now process a subset of the queries that
are waiting in the main cluster so we just offload those queries the
concurrent cluster has exactly the same view of data as your main thruster so there is no discrepancy there and the
results come back to the main and get back to the client so there is no application change to use this all
you have to do is in the workload manager turn on a checkbox to say that
you wished for this to happen if there is queuing and will automatically take care of all this behind the scenes what actually happens
is within a few seconds we are able to attach another cluster and get the query done so one of the things we decided to
do is not to wait fully rehydrate the concurrent clusters
with the data before query and the reason for this is twofold the first thing is it just takes a very long list
it takes a long time you're thinking of short bursts of activity you can't quite wait for your data set to fully be
hydrated there's physics involved there in moving data the second reason is it's going to be expensive the minute we start putting
your data on a cluster we have to start charging because nobody else can use that and I think that is also not ideal
given that these burst classes are going to be charged by the second of usage
it's far better to just use it for the duration of the query time itself what

scaling reads under the covers with many more nodes so we have a bunch of

see a couple of use cases that people are using this for and this is the feedback they've gotten one thing is
people say hey before I used to think about resizing up in anticipation of
more data that will come in a month from now now I don't have to do that I can just do it far closer to when the data

this helps just respond to that really fast and the third use case is I've also
seen customers resize up for let's say a month and ETL drop that's really heavy
so having those extra nodes deal with the ETL helps to make sure that the job

here is you know we we were doing all those best practices blogs and books
documented on best practices and they said hey you know it's very hard for people to go read this figure out how

things like using better compression schemes talking about data skew any number of things I think we have about

redshift advisor the other thing we've heard customers is from customers is we
